--- title: "INFO 511 - Group Final Project" subtitle: "Proposal: Milestone 2" author: - name: "Indecision Scientists" affiliations: - name: "College of Information Science, University of Arizona" format: html: code-tools: true code-overflow: wrap code-line-numbers: true embed-resources: true editor: visual code-annotations: hover execute: warning: false jupyter: python3 --- ::: {#load-pkgs .cell message='false' execution_count=1} ``` {.python .cell-code} import numpy as np import seaborn as sns import pandas as pd ``` ::: ## Introduction and data 1. **Remote Work & Mental Health** - **Source:** Kaggle - - **Collection date/method:** Data uploaded in September 2024 and collected from a variety of sources via the digital distribution of a structured questionnaire that anonymized responses on social media platforms, professional networks, and online forums - **Description:** This dataset comprises 5,000 employee records worldwide with details about work location, stress levels, mental health resource access, job satisfaction, and demographics (age, gender, industry, etc.) - **Ethical concerns:** N/A ::: {#91a474c7 .cell execution_count=2} ``` {.python .cell-code} remoteMH = pd.read_csv("data/RemoteWork_MentalHealth.csv") ``` ::: 2. **U.S. Natural Resources Revenue (2003-2023)** - **Source:** Kaggle - - **Collection date/method:** Data spanning 2003 to present collected and managed by the Department of the Interior's Office of Natural Resources Revenue - **Description:** This dataset comprises revenue generated from and attributes of natural U.S. resources such as federal lands, waters, and indigenous lands. Data includes land classification, lease types, revenue types, and commodities/products that are extracted from the natural resources. - **Ethical concerns:** Revenue data for indigenous/Native American resources was only reported at a national level to protect private/sensitive information ::: {#63d7dc2b .cell execution_count=3} ``` {.python .cell-code} natResRev = pd.read_csv("data/us_natResources_revenue.csv") ``` ::: 3. **Global Earthquake Data** - **Source:** Kaggle - - **Collection date/method:** Data collected using the *EveryEarthquake* API from *RapidAPI* with earthquakes from 6/23/2023 through 9/18/2024 - **Description:** This dataset comprises attributes and other details of 1,137 earthquakes from around the world including magnitude, location, date, time, and other measurements used in seismology - **Ethical concerns:** N/A ::: {#683a1fa4 .cell execution_count=4} ``` {.python .cell-code} quakes = pd.read_csv("data/earthquakes.csv") ``` ::: ## Research Question 1. **Remote Work & Mental Health** - **Research question:** How are employees' stress levels and mental health conditions related to work locations and employees' professional experience levels across age groups? Are changes in productivity associated with changes in physical activity and access to mental health resources? - **Importance:** Examining the relationships between the personal well-being of employees, increases in stress, decreases in productivity, and their working locations/arrangements can provide the foundation for future predictive studies/models that are more relevant than ever during a time when employers are determining whether returning employees to central offices presents greater benefit than keeping a hybrid or remote arrangement. - **Description:** This research delves into vocational psychology and its intersection with how technology has changed the work landscape. With the 2020 pandemic forcing employers to adopt remote and hybrid arrangements and post-pandemic "recovery" in the present day, discussions have evolved from the creative ways companies have been able to continue operation while staying home and quarantined to whether it is more beneficial for employees to return to social corporate settings (with a convenient benefit of preventing company losses due to expensive corporate real estate remaining empty). The hypotheses for this study are that younger employees have better mental health in hybrid and remote work locations than older employees (especially those with more years of experience since perhaps these employees are more used to in-person working environments), and increases in physical activity and access to mental health resources are associated with positive changes in productivity. - **Variable types:** - **Categorical:** Work location, Stress level, Mental health condition, Access to mental health resources, Productivity change, Physical activity - **Quantitative:** Age, Years of experience 2. **U.S. Natural Resources Revenue (2003-2023)** - **Research question:** In what ways have revenue patterns from renewable versus non-renewable resource extraction (e.g., geothermal, oil, and gas) evolved over the past two decades, and how does the interaction between resource type and land category (onshore versus offshore) influence these revenue trends across different regions? - **Importance:** This question leverages the datasetâ€™s extensive time span and diverse resource categories, addressing the critical topic of renewable versus non-renewable energy. It enables an exploration of long-term trends, analysis by land type, and comparisons across revenue sources, providing a relevant perspective on the economics of sustainable energy. - **Description:** This research examines revenue trends from renewable and non-renewable resources on federal and Native American lands over the past two decades, focusing on differences between onshore and offshore land categories. The study aims to reveal whether renewable resource revenue, particularly from geothermal energy, has grown over time relative to non-renewables like oil and gas. The hypothesis is that revenue from renewable resources has increased over time, while offshore lands generate higher revenue from non-renewables, and onshore lands contribute more to renewables. Additionally, non-renewable revenue remains high but fluctuates due to market and policy changes. - **Variable types:** - **Categorical:** Land Category, State, Commodity - **Quantitative:** Revenue, Calendar Year 3. **Global Earthquake Data** - **Research question:** Can we predict the impact and measure of an earthquake based on various factors, such as location, date, time, magnitude, or depth? - **Importance:** It would be nice to predict the impact of an earthquake to give estimations on recovery times/efforts needed by local governments if they we can accurately predict the impact. - **Description:** This topic covers earthquake data from around the world. Our hypothesis would be: you can predict the measure of impact an earthquake has based on various features of an earthquake. - **Variable types:** - **Object:** Time and date - **Quantitative (number):** Magnitude, depth, felt, cdi, mmi, sig, rms, gap - **Categorical:** Continent, country, alert ## Glimpse of data 1. **Remote Work & Mental Health** ::: {#383f1cd6 .cell execution_count=5} ``` {.python .cell-code} remoteMH.head() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=5} ```{=html}

``` ::: ::: ::: {#02db7e7a .cell execution_count=10} ``` {.python .cell-code} quakes.info() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` RangeIndex: 1137 entries, 0 to 1136 Data columns (total 43 columns): # Column Non-Null Count Dtype --- ------ -------------- ----- 0 id 1137 non-null object 1 magnitude 1137 non-null float64 2 type 1137 non-null object 3 title 1137 non-null object 4 date 1137 non-null object 5 time 1137 non-null int64 6 updated 1137 non-null int64 7 url 1137 non-null object 8 detailUrl 1137 non-null object 9 felt 1137 non-null int64 10 cdi 1137 non-null int64 11 mmi 1137 non-null int64 12 alert 764 non-null object 13 status 1137 non-null object 14 tsunami 1137 non-null int64 15 sig 1137 non-null int64 16 net 1137 non-null object 17 code 1137 non-null object 18 ids 1137 non-null object 19 sources 1137 non-null object 20 types 1137 non-null object 21 nst 1137 non-null int64 22 dmin 1137 non-null float64 23 rms 1137 non-null float64 24 gap 1137 non-null float64 25 magType 1137 non-null object 26 geometryType 1137 non-null object 27 depth 1137 non-null float64 28 latitude 1137 non-null float64 29 longitude 1137 non-null float64 30 place 1137 non-null object 31 distanceKM 1137 non-null int64 32 placeOnly 1137 non-null object 33 location 1137 non-null object 34 continent 867 non-null object 35 country 799 non-null object 36 subnational 716 non-null object 37 city 674 non-null object 38 locality 1137 non-null object 39 postcode 197 non-null float64 40 what3words 1137 non-null object 41 timezone 1137 non-null int64 42 locationDetails 1137 non-null object dtypes: float64(8), int64(10), object(25) memory usage: 382.1+ KB ``` ::: ::: ## Analysis plan 1. **Remote Work & Mental Health** - **Plan:** We will need to explore the unique values of some variables to determine the best way to group them in new variables for more generalized comparisons (i.e., age group comparisons, mental health conditions reported versus none reported, etc.). Once data wrangling is complete with the required additional variables created, we can visualize the data with various graphs to determine whether there are relationships among the variables selected. - **Variables to be created:** The ages of employees may need to be binned into age group categories. Similarly, the years of experience for employees may need to be binned into larger experience categories. A new binary variable will also be created to denote whether or not a mental health condition was reported. - **External data:** No external data to be merged. 2. **U.S. Natural Resources Revenue (2003-2023)** - **Plan:** Data wrangling will initially be required to create variables that group U.S. states into geographic regions so that we can compare the Revenue patterns across Calendar Years between Commodity types, Land Category, and geographic regions. We will also group renewable resources versus non-renewable resources. The comparisons will then primarily be done by constructing a variety of data visualizations. - **Variables to be created:** A categorical variable will be needed to identify whether a resource is considered renewable or non-renewable. Another categorical variable would be created to identify which geographic region a state that has a particular resource belongs to (e.g., Texas would be in the Southern region, etc.). - **External data:** No external data to be merged. 3. **Global Earthquake Data** - **Plan:** We will need to be more familiar with the type of earthquake features (e.g., cdi, rms, gap) to understand the features that are available for us to use. We will need to take a closer look at the data and then filter out any unnecessary features, and conduct data visualization. - **Variables to be created:** Currently there are no variables expected to be created. - **External data:** No external data to be merged.
